title: Late refund from loyal customer
situation: A customer who has been paying $150/month for 2.5 years is requesting a refund for a charge from 60 days ago. They say they meant to cancel before a 3-month sabbatical but forgot. They've been a great customer with no previous issues. What should we do?
expected_reasoning: Long-term customer value exceeds refund cost
vanilla_likely_response: Deny - policy says 30 days, no exceptions

title: Enterprise deal needs custom security terms
situation: We're in final negotiations with a large bank for a $800k/year deal. Their security team is requiring modifications to our standard security addendum - specifically around penetration testing rights and incident notification timelines. Our policy says no custom terms. How should we handle this?
expected_reasoning: Large enterprise deals in regulated industries get contract flexibility
vanilla_likely_response: Deny - policy says no custom contract terms

title: Disputed charge with evidence
situation: A customer is furious, saying they were charged $299 twice this month. They've attached a bank statement screenshot showing two identical charges on different days. They're threatening to do a chargeback if we don't refund immediately. Our system only shows one charge. What do we do?
expected_reasoning: Refund first to prevent chargeback, investigate after
vanilla_likely_response: Investigate first, then decide on refund

title: Competitor threat on key account
situation: Our customer success manager just learned that one of our $75k/year customers has been in active discussions with our main competitor. The customer mentioned they have a demo scheduled for next Tuesday. They haven't said they're leaving, but the signs are concerning. What's our play?
expected_reasoning: Proactive retention before they decide to leave
vanilla_likely_response: Wait for customer to make a decision, then respond

title: Locked out before important meeting
situation: An Enterprise customer ($150k/year) is locked out of their account - too many failed MFA attempts. They have an investor meeting in 90 minutes and desperately need access to their analytics dashboards. Our security policy requires a 24-hour review for locked accounts. What should we do?
expected_reasoning: Enterprise customers with verifiable identity can get expedited security review
vanilla_likely_response: Follow policy - 24 hour security review required, no exceptions

title: Free user demanding premium support
situation: A user on our free tier is sending angry emails demanding a phone call with our CEO about a bug they encountered. They're threatening to 'destroy our reputation on Twitter' if we don't respond within the hour. They've never paid us anything. How do we handle this?
expected_reasoning: Don't reward threatening behavior from non-paying users
vanilla_likely_response: Might suggest escalating to avoid bad PR

title: Expired card caused suspension
situation: A 3-year customer ($25k/year) just realized their service was suspended 2 weeks ago because their corporate card expired. They never saw our renewal emails (IT had them filtered). They want to pay immediately and restore access. Policy says suspended accounts need a review process. What do we do?
expected_reasoning: Established customers with payment issues get immediate restoration
vanilla_likely_response: Follow suspension review process as per policy

title: Startup needs trial extension
situation: A Sequoia-backed startup is on day 12 of their 14-day trial. Their VP of Engineering just went on emergency family leave and they're asking for a 3-week extension to properly evaluate when she returns. Based on their team size, they'd likely be a $25-30k/year customer. Should we extend?
expected_reasoning: Qualified startups with legitimate reasons get trial extensions
vanilla_likely_response: Deny - trial period is 14 days as stated

title: Wants retroactive promotional pricing
situation: A customer signed up 3 weeks ago at $400/month. They just saw we're running a 25% off promotion this week. They're asking if we can apply the discount to their existing subscription retroactively. They seem like a reasonable person, not angry. What's the right response?
expected_reasoning: No retroactive discounts, but offer future value to redirect
vanilla_likely_response: Deny - discounts are not retroactive per policy

title: Data export in special format for migration
situation: A $40k/year customer is migrating to a new BI tool and needs their historical data exported in Parquet format. Our policy says CSV only. They have 4 years of data and say converting from CSV would take their team weeks of work. They're asking nicely and this is their first special request ever. What should we do?
expected_reasoning: High-value customers with reasonable one-time requests get accommodated
vanilla_likely_response: Deny - policy says CSV format only
